awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Printing of Heterogeneous Tissue Constructs from Reactive Biomaterials using Intersecting Jets
awd_abstract_narration:
Inkjet bioprinting is an additive manufacturing approach for creating 3D tissue constructs using cell suspensions and hydrogels as bioinks. Many hydrogels and cell suspensions can be mixed to prepare cell-laden bioinks for traditional mixing-then-printing applications. However, some hydrogels are chemically reactive with cell suspensions upon mixing. Bioinks prepared by mixing these hydrogels and cell suspensions have significantly deteriorated printability and even are not printable at all. This GOALI award supports fundamental research on a mixing-while-printing approach to print reactive hydrogels and cell suspensions. Results from this research will expand the versatility of 3D inkjet bioprinting with reactive biomaterials. Printed heterogeneous tissue constructs can be used as organ models for various biomedical applications such as drug screening, and might be used for organ transplantation in the future.

With the mixing-while-printing approach, reactive hydrogels and cell suspensions are printed as two individual jets; the jets break up, intersect, and mix with each other due to droplet collision and coalescence, resulting in a gelled heterogeneous building block. The research objectives are two-fold: (1) to understand the effects of printing conditions on droplet formation, impingement, collision, and coalescence processes when using intersecting jets; and (2) to elucidate the influences of droplet impingement, collision, and coalescence on the material mixing performance during mixing-while-printing biofabrication. To achieve the first objective, cell-laden droplet formation process will be modeled using a volume of fluid-based computational approach to predict the droplet morphology, size, and velocity under different nozzle diameters and exciting voltages. Droplet impingement, collision, and coalescence processes will be modeled using a meshfree smooth particle hydrodynamic method under different intersecting angles and standoff distances. Some model predictions will be compared with experimental results, and the droplet morphology, size, and velocity before and after jet intersecting will be measured using high speed imaging. To achieve the second objective, material mixing performance will be evaluated in terms of how living cells are distributed in a printed structure. The mixing performance will be modeled using a set of material property and printing condition-related dimensionless numbers based on a scale analysis of governing conservation equations and interfacial conditions. Predicted mixing performance will be compared with the measured cell distribution of deposited droplets and fabricated tissue constructs using particle image velocimetry and optical imaging, respectively, under different droplet impingement, collision, and coalescence scenarios.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
While conventional three-dimensional (3D) bioprinting technologies are suitable for many tissue engineering applications, emerging biomaterials and constructs still call for bioprinting innovations. There is a need for the fabrication of complex heterogeneous structures from reactive biomaterials. During reactive material printing, reactive solutions/suspensions which undergo changes in rheological properties or cytocompatibility are not printable using traditional bioprinting approaches since they require all components of bioinks to be mixed before printing. To resolve this manufacturing-related challenge during reactive material printing, an intersecting-jets inkjet bioprinting approach has been proposed and studied for its practical applications. During the intersecting-jets printing process, reactive materials are ejected from different inkjet nozzles, and they collide, mix, and react in situ to form a voxel-type building block for 3D bioprinting.

 

The study has resulted in new knowledge of the intersecting-jets inkjet bioprinting protocol for voxel-resolution printing-then-mixing applications. Specifically, inkjetting-based intersecting-jets printing has been implemented as a versatile technique to simultaneously deposit droplets of disparate reactive materials at controlled locations where active collision, mixing, and coalescence occur. Alginate structures have also been printed in air directly from reactive sodium alginate and calcium chloride solutions, and neural stem cell (NSC) spheres have been fabricated from a reactive PuraMatrix hydrogel solution and physiological cell suspension. It has been found that the printing performance can be further improved by utilizing a liquid absorbing system to remove excess water generated during the printing process. In addition, the effect of printing conditions on the behavior of droplets during layer formation has been modeled based on the gelation dynamics to enable the controllable and reliable fabrication of gel structures. The effect of gelation on the droplet impact dynamics has been found to be negligible during alginate printing, and the resulting gel interfaces have been found to form between printed lines within a layer depending on the printing conditions, printing path orientation, and gelation dynamics. While satisfactory mixing performance (>90%) can be obtained under ideal printing conditions, it has been found that the mixing performance during intersecting-jets printing is affected by the spatial and temporal offsets of intersecting jets, and such effects are also influenced by the rheological properties and reactivities of ink materials. While the intersecting-jets printing process is a complicated process that may involve complex fluids as ink materials, it has been found that the mixing performance and its variation can still be satisfactorily predicted by using an artificial neural network-based modeling approach.

 

As an additive manufacturing (AM) technique, the intersecting-jets printing technology can be utilized to print 3D engineering parts and tissue scaffolds from reactive materials, which are not printable using the conventional inkjet printing approach. This printing technology can be utilized for the printing of heterogeneous structures by dispensing different materials at a controllably different frequency. In particular, the intersecting-jets printing technology enables the biofabrication of heterogeneous tissue scaffolds from reactive materials. It benefits the biomedical discipline as it is a novel technology for freeform tissue engineering using reactive biomaterials. In addition, four Ph.D., one M.S., and one undergraduate students have been trained in the course of this research project, and the resulting knowledge has been disseminated as journal publications as well as integrated into teaching materials.


Last Modified: 09/30/2021
Modified by: Yong Huang
